conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases, we need to analyze the given velocity-time (v-t) graph.
Particle A: The deceleration phase starts at t = t0 and ends at t = 3t0.
Particle B: The deceleration phase starts at t = 5t0 and ends at t = 6t0.

premise: Initial velocity (vi) at t = t0: 2v0; Final velocity (vf) at t = 3t0: v0
conclusion: Change in velocity (ΔvA) for Particle A: vf - vi = v0 - 2v0 = -v0

premise: Initial velocity (vi) at t = 5t0: v0; Final velocity (vf) at t = 6t0: 0
conclusion: Change in velocity (ΔvB) for Particle B: vf - vi = 0 - v0 = -v0

premise: Deceleration phase for Particle A: t = t0 to t = 3t0
conclusion: Time interval (ΔtA) for Particle A: 3t0 - t0 = 2t0

premise: Deceleration phase for Particle B: t = 5t0 to t = 6t0
conclusion: Time interval (ΔtB) for Particle B: 6t0 - 5t0 = t0
Acceleration (aA) for Particle A: aA = ΔvA / ΔtA = -v0 / 2t0 = -v0 / 2t0
Acceleration (aB) for Particle B: aB = ΔvB / ΔtB = -v0 / t0 = -v0 / t0

premise: Magnitude of aA: |-v0 / 2t0| = v0 / 2t0; Magnitude of aB: |-v0 / t0| = v0 / t0
conclusion: The ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations is: (v0 / 2t0) / (v0 / t0) = 1/2
